citations.narrative:
Within the past 1.5 years, multiple animals were found deceased due to trauma or predation.
*Records show that one female blackbuck was found deceased on 6/23/23. Records state that the cause of death was
trauma, and in the herd disposition record this death is attributed to predation.
*Records show that one male red lechwe was found deceased on 3/26/23. Records state that the cause of death was
gore wounds. The herd disposition record this death is coded as "other".
*The herd record shows that one female llama was found deceased on 9/20/22 and the cause of death is recorded as
"other". According to the Assistant Director, a field necropsy was performed on this llama and the cause of death was
attributed to extensive bleeding in the chest cavity caused by trauma. There are no records from the field necropsy.
*Records show that one male llama was found deceased on 1/13/23 and the cause of death was attributed to trauma; the
herd disposition record attributes this death to "other". The animal received extensive medical care prior to its death.
*Records show that one blackbuck was found deceased on 4/28/22 and one female impala was found deceased on
12/20/22, and for both animals the cause of death was attributed to predation. There were no necropsy reports available
for these animals. According to the Park Manager, when the cause of death is obvious such as death by predation, a
necropsy is not performed.
Animals that experience physical trauma, goring, or who are killed by predators may experience stress, fear, and pain.
Correct by August 7th, 2023 by ensuring that animals are handled as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner
that does not cause trauma, overheating, excessive cooling, behavioral stress, physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort.

The kangaroo exhibit does not have an adequate public barrier to protect the animals and the public. Eleven intact adult
male red kangaroos are housed in a large outdoor enclosure. There is a public walkway that passes through the center of
the enclosure; the walkway is lined on both sides by a barrier made of multiple vertical posts approximately 4 feet tall
connected together by three horizontal strands of taught wire. One kangaroo was observed laying close to the barrier,
within an arm’s length of the fence. The Park Director stated that sometimes the kangaroo will pass through the barrier
and cross the walkway in order to get to the other side of the exhibit. There is no attendant supervising or preventing
public contact in this exhibit. A sign at the entrance to the exhibit instructs visitors to stay on the path and prohibits feeding
the animals.
Without adequate barrier or supervision, animals or members of the public may cause harm to one another.
Correct by 8/11/23 by ensuring that there is adequate distance and/or barriers in place to prevent unauthorized contact
between animals and members of the public. Corrected at the time of the exit briefing.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Park Director.
n

narrative:
2.131(b)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
Within the past 1.5 years, multiple animals were found deceased due to trauma or predation.  
*Records show that one female blackbuck was found deceased on 6/23/23. Records state that the cause of death was 
trauma, and in the herd disposition record this death is attributed to predation. 
*Records show that one male red lechwe was found deceased on 3/26/23. Records state that the cause of death was 
gore wounds. The herd disposition record this death is coded as "other". 
*The herd record shows that one female llama was found deceased on 9/20/22 and the cause of death is recorded as 
"other". According to the Assistant Director, a field necropsy was performed on this llama and the cause of death was 
attributed to extensive bleeding in the chest cavity caused by trauma. There are no records from the field necropsy. 
*Records show that one male llama was found deceased on 1/13/23 and the cause of death was attributed to trauma; the 
herd disposition record attributes this death to "other". The animal received extensive medical care prior to its death.  
*Records show that one blackbuck was found deceased on 4/28/22 and one female impala was found deceased on 
12/20/22, and for both animals the cause of death was attributed to predation. There were no necropsy reports available 
for these animals. According to the Park Manager, when the cause of death is obvious such as death by predation, a 
necropsy is not performed.  
Animals that experience physical trauma, goring, or who are killed by predators may experience stress, fear, and pain.  
Correct by August 7th, 2023 by ensuring that animals are handled as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner 
that does not cause trauma, overheating, excessive cooling, behavioral stress, physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort. 
2.131(c)(1) 
   
Handling of animals. 
The kangaroo exhibit does not have an adequate public barrier to protect the animals and the public. Eleven intact adult 
male red kangaroos are housed in a large outdoor enclosure. There is a public walkway that passes through the center of 
the enclosure; the walkway is lined on both sides by a barrier made of multiple vertical posts approximately 4 feet tall 
connected together by three horizontal strands of taught wire. One kangaroo was observed laying close to the barrier, 
within an arm’s length of the fence. The Park Director stated that sometimes the kangaroo will pass through the barrier 
and cross the walkway in order to get to the other side of the exhibit. There is no attendant supervising or preventing 
public contact in this exhibit. A sign at the entrance to the exhibit instructs visitors to stay on the path and prohibits feeding 
the animals.

Without adequate barrier or supervision, animals or members of the public may cause harm to one another.  
Correct by 8/11/23 by ensuring that there is adequate distance and/or barriers in place to prevent unauthorized contact 
between animals and members of the public. Corrected at the time of the exit briefing. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Park Director.

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
